text: The ad has been playing on a 13-inch TV in a small, wood- paneled office. A handful of EMPLOYEES and FAMILY MEMBERS applaud wildly. The proud owner of Northlands, BILL KROGS 60, embraces the man of the hour, Roger Lemke.
sense_profile: A handful of EMPLOYEES and FAMILY MEMBERS

text: Ho-lee Christmas, knocked her outta the park, Roger! Out of the G-D park, you sonofagun! 2. Cedar Rapids, 6-12-09

Hell, I'm just a pretty face, Bill. That copy was all you. Do got one little gripe though, boss-- if you'd waited until after Cedar Rapids we could've said winner of the Two Diamonds four years running!
Aroo-aroo! Two Diamonds! Two Diamonds! The men roughhouse playfully. Roger's comely wife, GWEN, holding their milk-fed TWIN TODDLERS, gives Roger a kiss.
sense_profile: Roger 's comely wife , GWEN , holding their milk - fed TWIN TODDLERS

text: So proud of you, Roggie. God, you rock. Doesn't your dad rock, boys?!

(an Elvis impersonation) Thank you. Thank you very much! More laughter and backslapping. After a bit, an as yet un MAN hesitantly approaches. He gently touches Roger's arm, wanting to interrupt the revelry. Roger turns.
Tim! Timmy Lippe! Didn't even know you were here. You see it, bud?

(earnest, deeply admiring) Oh, heck yeah. You were awesome. Despite appearances to the contrary, this is our hero: TI LIPPE (pronounced Lippy), 34, wholesome and positive, tho undercurrents of desperation lurk just behind his kind ey
Just super... super awesome. Man.

Y'know what Tim, I want people to see the insurance game for what it really is-- it's a noble field. I believe that. Like I say, we're not just insuring vehicles and homes and that. Hell no. We're insuring people's dreams.
Oh. Yeah. I say that, too... sometimes. 3. Cedar Rapids, 6-12-09
Well shit, you do, don't you? By god, I stole your line! Knew I'd heard that somewhere!
Oh, no biggie...
Bummer they cut your little deal outta the ad, though.
Ach. Y'know. Got left on the ol'... A FEMALE CO-WORKER interrupts, accosts Roger and ignores
Roger! Look out Brad Pitt!
The ol' cutting room floor, right? (upon being ignored) Brad Pitt. Ha. That's... (then, with forced nonchalance) Whoa. Cake. Cool. Tim goes to the cake table. He smiles at the cake, impres
So awesome. The icing on the cake, a frosted visage of Roger Lemke, smiles back.

A beige Buick Skylark splashes through a puddle of snow m in the glum, isolated hamlet of Brown Valley, WI (pop: 33 Tim bops his head and sings along as a Parliament song pl on a Good Times, Great Oldies radio station. A dour OLD L shoveling her driveway stares as he passes by.
The Skylark pulls into the driveway of a tidy umber-color rambler with a nature scene painted on the garage door. 4. Cedar Rapids, 6-12-09
sense_profile: into the driveway of a tidy umber - color rambler with a nature scene painted on the garage door

text: Flowered wallpaper. Vinyl flooring. A spoon collection. T room looks like someone's grandmother designed it. Tim en He opens the fridge, grabs an A & W Root Beer. He opens a cupboard, removes a box of Hostess Cupcakes. He sits at t Formica kitchen table, meticulously eats the cupcake, sip soda pop and stares out the window at a bird feeder.

Tim's bedroom looks like that of a fastidious teenager. T bed. Orderly desk. Milwaukee Brewers poster (circa 1987). Tim removes his penny loafers, pleated khakis and Northla Insurance polo shirt. He puts on a different pair of plea khakis, a maroon turtleneck and some Top-siders.
sense_profile: like that of a fastidious teenager
his penny loafers , pleated khakis and Northla Insurance polo shirt

text: Tim enters another bedroom. This one has a four-poster be clearly a parents room, clearly unused. He opens the clos A label reads GIFT CLOSET!!! Each shelf is neatly organiz Toys, knickknacks, occasion-specific greeting cards. He selects a Get Well card and a Beanie Baby duck, Quackers. A doorbell RINGS. Tim hurriedly signs the card. He licks envelope as he hustles to the door.
Tim opens the door to MILLIE VANDERHEI, 54, a thick, depressive woman dressed like a 7th grade science teacher
sense_profile: the door to MILLIE VANDERHEI , 54 , a thick , depressive woman dressed like a 7th grade science teacher

text: There she is! How you feeling?
Oh, it's no big whoop. Tim pulls the card and Beanie Baby duck from behind his b
Ta-da. (re. the stuffed duck) Quack, quack. D'you already have this guy? Wasn't sure. 5. Cedar Rapids, 6-12-09

Gayle Syrstad gave me a Quackers for Secret Santa last year. I can probably trade with Nan, though. Millie sits on Tim's paisley sofa. She opens the card. On front: a Rottweiler in a nurse's outfit. Inside: "Get Wel You Deal with Me!" Then in Tim's writing, "Love, Tim."
(chuckles at the card) Cute. Brandy would never sit still long enough for me to dress her up like that. Tell you that right now.
You didn't have to do this whole rigmarole, Tim. I told you it's just a little diarrhea.
I know. But for you to miss a day of school, Millie... I can't remember you ever calling in sick when I had you.
Well I wasn't going through menopause when you were in middle school now was I?
Negative. Not to my knowledge. Not to my knowledge. She nods somberly. They sit there silently for a bit. The
So. Does your tummy feel good enough to...? They exchange a look...

Millie rides Tim. Tim palms her breasts. He still has on maroon turtleneck. And one brown sock. Their bodies make sound like two soft, thick hands apathetically applauding Clap-pfft, clop-pfft, clap-ffft. The twin bed squeaks disapprovingly. 6. Cedar Rapids, 6-12-09
sense_profile: sound like two soft , thick hands apathetically applauding Clap - pfft , clop - pfft , clap - ffft

text: I can try and... hold it, Mil. Can you...?
Bring it home. Bring it home. She waggles her hips with a bit more gusto. He grimaces.
I'm bringing it. Bringing it! Bringing it! D'aaaarrgho'awesome... Tim exhales. Millie exhales. That worked out well.
Millie and Tim watch American Idol. A WOMAN sings Queen's YOU'RE MY BEST FRIEND. Tim harmonizes.
Ooh, you make me live! You're my best friend!
C'mon Tim, I can't hear.
Sorry. But you are, babygirl.
You're my best friend.
Tss. Goofball. The song ends. They sit quietly for a bit.
Y'know Galen and Dar Krause just did a cruise to the Bahamas? Pretty reasonable they said, price-wise.
(mediocre Jamaican accent) Ya mon, Bahama-mama.
It's a little different I suppose-- a cruise. But... A beat, then Millie removes a cruise brochure from her pu 7. Cedar Rapids, 6-12-09
Look, I'm not gonna shilly-shally around here, Tim. I found a river cruise through Germany-- Viking Line, real grade-A. It's what I want. For the honeymoon.
Whoa, whoa, whoa, whoa. Wait... Where's this coming from? We agreed on Wisconsin Dells for the honeymoon. It's what we agreed on.
You've been to the Dells two dozen times...
So? Roger and Gwen Lemke go to the Dells every year...
Because they have children. Water parks are for children...
Hello, Tommy Bartlett's Ski, Sky and Stage Show? It's not just a water park...
Timothy, settle. You've never even left the state of Wisconsin. Barely left Brown Valley...
What's so great about...? You're not... You're missing the... We agreed on the Dells. He avoids eye contact. Millie takes Tim's chin in her han forcing him to look at her.
God rest her. Your mom was my best friend. But it's going on 20 years now. You gotta grow up. You gotta let go. You gotta live a life here. See?
I'm living a perfectly fine life. I don't know why you'd want to...
Cedar Rapids, 6-12-09

rock the waters or whatever. Ridiculous. Tim looks away again, pouting. Millie gives him a motherl hug. Over her shoulder, Tim watches a TEENAGER belting ou QUE SERA, SERA on American Idol. Then, almost inaudibly:
We agreed on the Dells.
IN BLACK, a phone RINGS.
Tim sleeps alone in his twin bed. The phone rings again. wakes with a start. He flips on the lamp, picks up the ph
Hello... Oh, hey Bill... A look of profound anguish appears on Tim's face.
Aw jeez. Oh my gosh. No... The sound of a church organ playing ON EAGLES WINGS fades
In back of a packed church, Millie whispers with WADE BRO 60, a bald, bullet-shaped man. The conversation is discre
sense_profile: In back of a packed church

text: Guy had it all. Everything you'd ever want. Y'know he flew a Cessna? In his spare time?
I always say people like that-- who live fast? They die hard. Look at River Phoenix.
Everything you'd ever want.
I just don't know. To do those things to yourself. Just perverted.
Who ever heard of such a thing? 9. Cedar Rapids, 6-12-09

Roger Lemke looks peaceful in death, although it's hard t miss the marks on his neck left behind by the belt. Tim i the front of a long line of uneasy MOURNERS. Tim holds ba tears as he gently touches the marks on Lemke's neck. Tim steps aside to greet the widow Gwen Lemke in a receiv line. The grief has left her gaunt. She appears medicated
sense_profile: Tim i the front of a long line of uneasy MOURNERS. Tim

text: I'm... Gwen, I'm so sorry. Roger is-- was-- is-- a personal hero to me. He just... he had it all. If there's... He is interrupted by Bill Krogstad's sobs. Tim reaches ou put a comforting hand on Gwen's shoulder, but somehow end touching her breast instead. A moment.
I'm... Tim nods sadly as he removes his hand. He walks away.

The drab office is brightened with week-old funeral flowe and flaccid mylar sympathy balloons. Tim sits across from a young couple, KURT & PAM GAMBSKY, in a small, glassed-in conference room. The couple is ten
You just don't get it, Kurt...
Aw Christ, Pammy...

Hang on guys, how's this sound-- you can both be right. (pause for effect) I know you're probably thinking, "Oh, an umbrella policy's only for rich people." You know what I say to that? Bull roar. The Gambskys smile, comforted. Tim is good at his job. 10. Cedar Rapids, 6-12-09

Pam, Kurt-- I've known you guys since you were little kids. So let's don't think of me as an "insurance salesman." Think of me as your friend who just wants to help you protect your dreams... Tim glances up and sees Bill Krogstad staring longingly a Northlands' three TWO DIAMOND Award plaques. A beat, then Krogstad SLAMS HIS FIST THROUGH THE WOOD PANELED WALL! Th couple reels around upon hearing the sound.
I'm... Excuse me a sec... Tim exits the conference room and approaches Krogstad, wh hand is now bleeding.
D'you-- can I get you a napkin or something, Bill? For that?
Know how Roger used to get down there to Cedar Rapids? To the ASMI Convention? Any idea?
Um. I'm with Kurt and Pam Gambsky...
Flew himself. In a Cessna. Pilot. (a mournful beat) It was all worked out. I was going to ease into retirement in July while Roger transitioned into his ownership role.
Wait, Roger was going to buy Northlands?
All worked out. Shit, Dione already put the down payment on a time share. Branson, Black Hills. Florida. Units all over the place.
Holy cow. 11. Cedar Rapids, 6-12-09

Yeah, whole deal. Now? Now I got my back up against Christ-knows-what. No Lemke, no buyer, the wife's spending like we won the goddamn Powerball. And what's worse, because of the way, y'know, the way Roger passed... Krogstad chokes up. His grief is very real. So is Tim's.
The... belt and the lederhosen...?
(a nod, a sigh) Quote-unquote perverted, they're saying. Like Northlands has some kind of stain. Oh, I'm so goddamned tired...

Is there...? Can I do anything to help, or...? Krogstad hands Tim a Manila folder (bloodying it in the process). Tim gestures for his customers to hold tight. T opens the folder, reading aloud from a cover page.
"Innovations in Hog Farm Risk Mitigation." Roger's Two Diamond presentation for the ASMI Convention. I helped prepare it.
We need those Two Diamonds more than ever, Tim. If I'm going to sell this company, we need people to feel OK about the Northlands brand.
(not getting it) Mm.
I'd go myself but my daughter Kayla, the heavy one? She unearthed some Polack to marry her. I'm locked into that wedding over in Gladstone. No flex. Locked in. 12. Cedar Rapids, 6-12-09
Whoa-whoa-wait. What are you saying?
I'm not asking you to fill Roger Lemke's shoes. Not gonna happen. I'm asking you to deliver his presentation-- to bring me home those Two Diamonds.
I can't go to ASMI. To Iowa. To Cedar Rapids, Iowa... Why can't Lila do it?
C'mon Tim. Lila's about as charismatic as a bag of hair.
Bill, I've never... I mean, I've dabbled in hog farm risk mitigation, but I'm no pro... Tim is really starting to panic.

You were what, 16, when I gave you that filing job? Right after your mom passed? Raising yourself pretty much, living all alone. And I'm thinking, now here's a kid. Here's a kid who's gonna go places. (a hand on Tim's shoulder) And then, somehow, you kind of just didn't. Now, I guess it makes some sense-- a child loses both parents at an early age, becomes what you might call stunted. But cripes almighty, do you want to just sit there in your folks old house, just rot away in Brown Valley dating that...
... woman the rest of your life?
Millie and I are getting married.
Tss, maybe three'll be a charm. (then, emotional)
Cedar Rapids, 6-12-09

Point is, I'm not exactly dancing in the streets here Tim, but it's a perception thing. You go down there to Cedar Rapids, wholesome and pie- eyed and all that. You show them that Northlands is a good outfit-- an upstanding Christian outfit... Tim considers the gravity of this moment.

Aw cripes, say you'll do it. Krogstad starts crying again. He hugs Tim, his bloody han staining Tim's canary yellow V-neck sweater. Tim looks up see the Gambskys in the conference room staring at him.
sense_profile: in the conference room staring at him

text: A melancholic yet uplifting song (Leonard Cohen's HALLELU perhaps) plays as: - Tim puts birdseed in his backyard feeder. He looks at t barren trees as he considers his fate. - Tim Googles "Cedar Rapids." He looks at photos, crime statistics, a Chamber of Commerce Youtube video. He close his eyes, exhales. - Tim practices the presentation in front of a mirror. He works late. He types. He Power Points. Krogstad critiques - Tim laminates maps of Cedar Rapids and area attractions - Tim pulls a dusty American Tourister suitcase from the attic. It looks about 40 years old. He packs.

Tim looks pensive as he drives. He's wearing a new suit. a little too big. A greeting card and a Beanie Baby Roost bounce along on the passenger's seat. Tim pulls up to a SPLIT-LEVEL HOUSE. A pick-up truck with words Brodt Heating & Cooling is parked in the driveway.

Tim pokes his head into a living room, surprised to see W the 60-ish bald guy from church, reclining on a Lazy Boy. 14. Cedar Rapids, 6-12-09 Wade's boots are off. His socks are dirty. He's watching on a TV with an Olan-Mills portrait of Tim & Millie atop
sense_profile: W the 60-ish bald guy from church

text: Oh, hiya Tim.
Hey. Wade. Hey. Is Millie...? Millie enters in a terry cloth robe. A Yorkshire Terrier follows her. Millie acts nonchalant. So does the dog.
Hi Tim. (re. Wade's presence) Wade's cable's down.
It's six AM...?
Mike & Mike in the Morning. ESPN 2.
Oh yeah. Those guys. Hilarious. Ha.
Mm.

(finally, to Millie) Well I just wanted to... He displays the Beanie Baby and the card. She takes them a cold smile. Tim notices an identical stuffed rooster on oak bookshelf-- home to over 155 other Beanie Babies.
Oh shoot. You already have a Strut the Rooster...
So this is it then?
Tim's jetting off to Cedar Rapids this morning, Wade. Big deal insurance convention. Iowa.
That right?
It's only four days. 15. Cedar Rapids, 6-12-09
Won't go to Germany for our honeymoon, but for work you can just gallivant around like Tom Petty or one of them?
We agreed on the Dells... (then, to Millie) Should we maybe talk in the...?
Oh it don't bother me. Tim tries to proceed as if Wade weren't sitting there.
If I don't try to do this, it's not just my job, Mil. There are four other employees whose lives are on the line. Plus Carol, who does part time seasonal work. So.
It's not for certain a new owner would even keep you guys on.
No, Bill said he'd make that part of any deal...
Believe you me, Bill Krogstad is looking out for one guy. And that's Bill Krogstad.
Krogstad. Tim shoots Wade a look.

It's... Oh, who am I kidding, I'm a little scared here. A lot scared. But not about us. What we've got-- we're like lightning in a bottle, babygirl. I love you so much, Mil. He hugs her. Millie melts just a little, yet remains ster
I want you to be very careful. 16. Cedar Rapids, 6-12-09

I know. I will. I mean, Cedar Rapids-- there were only four homicides last year. For a city of 122-thousand that's pretty darn good. The forcible rape numbers are admittedly a bit higher, but... She fidgets with his tie. A bitter tear skulks down her c
I want you to check in with me.
I will every day. Twice a day.
Make it three times.
OK, three times! Sheesh. And I'll send a stinkin' telegram, too. Tim kisses the warm tears from Millie's ruddy cheeks. Mil licks her finger and smooths Tim's cowlick. Wade just sit there watching.
Tim walks up to the tiny municipal airport. He tries the door. It's locked. A RETARDED MAN shoveling snow spots Ti
Airport don't open for two hours.
Thanks! Just wanna be sure I make my flight. Going down to Cedar Rapids. The big ASMI Convention? The retarded man nods vacantly and goes back to shoveling
Tim is the first (and only) person in the security line. apathetic TSA AGENT awaits him. Tim has a nervous energy. 17. Cedar Rapids, 6-12-09
Cold enough for you? I'm heading to Cedar Rapids. Supposed to be up in the mid-30s down there. S-weet!
Any liquids, gels or aerosols must be placed in a quart-size Zip-Lock. Laptop computers must be taken out of the case and placed in...
Whoa... what's all this now?
Any liquids, gels or aerosols...
Tim! Praise Christ you haven't left yet. Bill Krogstad runs up to Tim. He's out of breath.
Hey Bill, what's going on?
Can't believe I forgot to get this to you. Hang on, lemme... Krogstad puts his hands on his knees, takes a few deep breaths. Then he hands Tim a detailed handwritten checkli
It's basically an ASMI Convention Bible. It's going to tell you who to talk to, who to avoid, how best to fellowship and network... Tim glances at the list, reads the only name under AVOID.
sense_profile: how best to fellowship and network ... Tim glances at the list

text: Dean Ziegler, Stevens Point.

Ziegler is a cancer. Sonofabitch called one of Lemke's biggest clients-- Joyce Armbruster? Smeared Roger's name and the Northlands' name. Frickin' poacher. Avoid Ziegler like the plague. The fella I got you rooming with, Ronald Wilkes-- that's who you stick by. 18. Cedar Rapids, 6-12-09 By Ziegler's name, Tim frantically writes, "Poacher" and "Armbruster--" making sure not to forget the umlaut.
You got the presentation, right?
Affirmative. Tim untucks his shirt, revealing a zippered cummerbund-li money belt.
On me at all times. Plus three back- up discs.

Hey-hey! That kind of prep is pure Lemke! Didn't know any better, I'd say Roger's spirit had kind of climbed into you, just planted its seed inside you there. Atta boy! High praise indeed. Tim hesitates. Is now the right time?
Bill... I have to ask. Let's say one of these big dogs-- your Allstates, your Prudentials-- does decide to go and buy Northlands...?

Said it before, I'll say it again: Your job, the office in Brown Valley-- all safe. What you need to worry about is getting down there and representing us the best you can. That's all you need to worry about. Tim swallows hard. Bill brings it in for a hug and inhale Tim's hair.
Tim has a window seat. He reads the safety card. He's swe anxious. A vaguely swarthy MAN (Indian? Italian? Hard to tell.), 40s, sits next to him. A perky FLIGHT ATTENDANT approaches.
You lucky ducks are obviously seated in an exit row. Score!
Cedar Rapids, 6-12-09
Just gotta make sure you're willing and able to assist crew members in the event of an emergency evacuation... The man smiles nonchalantly. Tim tries to play it cool.
sense_profile: in the event of an emergency evacuation

text: You're talking what, water landing? (looks around, whispers) Terror type deal? Terrorists...?
It's really just a formality.
Believe it or not, I have actually never been on an airplane before.
Oh, well you'll do awesome.
(takes a moment) OK. If you need any help, I'm in. The flight attendant smiles politely, if confusedly.
Tim looks out the window, watching nervously as the dairy farms and frozen lakes of northern Wisconsin recede. He instinctively turns to his neighbor.
Tim Lippe.
Ah. David Marinakis. They shake hands.
Great to meet you, Dave. Wondering, what kind of name is Marinakis?
Greek. It's Greek.
Marinakis. OK. Mine's German. Lippe.
Cedar Rapids, 6-12-09

As in, "Don't you get lippy with me, mister." My grandma used to say that. Before she passed. Lot of people pronounce it lip. Course the high German's probably more like lipp-uh. David Marinakis nods, goes back to his book, seemingly shutting down the conversation. Tim settles in.
Tim hesitates before stepping onto the jetway-- one small step for man-- and just like that, he's in IOWA!
Tim helps David Marinakis take his bag off the carousel.
sense_profile: take his bag off the carousel

text: Like I say, Dave, it's not life insurance so much as it is dream insurance.
It's a good way of looking at it.
I think so. Tim hands David his card, who takes it with a genuine smi
Let me know how things go with your Alltel deal, Dave. E-mail me.
Will do, Tim. Thanks. David exits. Tim stands there waving.
Tim emerges from an elevator on the roof of a parking gar He inhales the chilly Iowa air. He glances at his rental agreement and spots his car, a red Chevy Cobalt.
Hello. Score! As he approaches the car, he stops. He chuckles, in awe. 21. Cedar Rapids, 6-12-09
Holy crap. Awesome. In the distance, the Cedar Rapids skyline looms-- its tal building, the Alliant Tower stretching 21 stories into th cloudy sky. Tim snaps a photo with his cell phone.

The Holidome sign reads, Welcome ASMI `09 Participants!!! gets out of the rental car. He looks around-- not too sha But upon spotting a SIKH CABBIE in a turban, Tim straight up and cautiously adjusts his money cummerbund. As he walks toward the entrance, a pretty but gaunt young woman in a short denim skirt, BREE, 22, approaches him.
sense_profile: As he walks toward the entrance

text: Hey man, can I bum a heater?
What's that now?
A cigarette?
Oh, I'm like, "this gal wants to borrow my heater?" Tss. But no, sorry, can't help you there.
You here for the convention?
You bet. Tim Lippe. Northlands Insurance. How `bout yourself?
Ah, Bree. I'm Bree. They shake hands.
Well Bree, it's nice to meet you. But let me give you a trade secret.
Keep smoking and your premiums will go through the roof.
Thanks Mr. Surgeon General. (they laugh, then)
Cedar Rapids, 6-12-09
If you want to party, Tim, let me know. I'll be around.
You bet. Party hearty. Nice chatting with you, Bree. People are so friendly. Tim enters the hotel.

Tim walks in. He strolls atop the velvety green carpet, p a fountain, beneath a golden-colored chandelier and makes way to the front desk-- blown away. An apple-cheeked cler whose name tag reads TRENT, greets him.
sense_profile: p a fountain , beneath a golden - colored chandelier and
way to the front desk-- blown away

text: Checking in with us, sir?
You tell me. Never done the hotel deal before.
Well, welcome. I'll just need to see a credit card for the incidentals...
(reads the name tag) Trent, I was given the impression that you honored traveler's checks.
Yes, we just need an imprint of your card. For the incidentals.
Traveler's check is a fully insured method of, y'know. 100 percent.
I'm aware of that, sir. We won't charge the card unless you rent a movie or take something from the mini-bar...
I'm a non-drinker.
It's standard, sir. 23. Cedar Rapids, 6-12-09 Tim eyes Trent cautiously as he unzips his cummerbund/mon belt. He removes a credit card and reluctantly hands it o
Cell phone to his ear, Tim struggles with his bag as he w to his room.
Have you seen the pool yet?

Not yet, but I can smell it. The chlorine. It's a super top-notch place, Mil. You'd be blown away. Oop, 321. I'm at mi casa. Just a... lemme see how this deal works. He examines the card key. He slides it in. It doesn't wor Tries again. Doesn't work. Each time he fails, it beeps.
Key's like a stinkin' credit card. Suddenly, the door opens. And standing before Tim is a BL MAN. Tim gasps, drops his suitcase, backs away.
What? What happened?
(to the man) Oh jeez. I'm sorry. I'm... Please. (turns, whispers into phone) There's an Afro-American gentleman in this room.
Well get the heck outta there! Tim turns back and smiles, frightened. The man looks conf
Tim! Run like hell, Tim!
Are you Tim? Tim Lippe? Tim just smiles a wide, deer-in-headlights smile.
I'm Ronald Wilkes. Bill Krogstad said we were gonna be roommates? 24. Cedar Rapids, 6-12-09 RONALD WILKES, 45, is conservative in dress and demeanor.
Tim! Tim! Tiiim!
Let me call you back, Mil. Tim clicks off his phone, just stares at Ronald.
You are Tim...?
Um. Yeah. Yes. You bet. For a minute there I was like, whoa, I'm gonna be robbed here, or... Tim laughs loudly. Ronald just looks at Tim. A beat.
It's super... just super great to meet you, Ronald. Tim shakes Ronald's hand, holds onto it for at least two seconds too long.
OK. You want to check out the room then?
Ronald leads Tim into the room, a junior suite with two b a kitchenette and a couch in the separate living room are
Check out these digs. Huzzah!

Yeah, you could do a lot worse. (a serious beat) Look Tim, I gotta put the cards on the table here. The reason we got the junior suite upgrade is because the hotel overbooked-- wedding or some such. Point being, they were asking folks to take on a third roommate to consolidate space. Now to me, being an independent owner, the savings of adding a third guy sounded like a real positive.
Cedar Rapids, 6-12-09
But if you've got any qualms, I hear you L & C, that's Loud & Clear. Ronald has undoubtedly been called a nerd more than once. Tim, however, he is the embodiment of cool and hilarity.
No. I'm down. Down with that. Heck yeah. Any idea who we're gonna be chilling with, roommate-wise?
No. Just hope he doesn't snore.
Can you imagine? Or someone who has terrible gas?! Like, pull my finger. Brrump! Hello, no thanks! Tim is giddy like a kid away at camp for the first time.
This isn't Woodstock, Tim. It's a regional insurance convention. Whoever it is, I'm sure he'll be a straight shooter.
A pair of massive, scuffed wing-tips walk determinedly do the hall. We don't see the man they belong to, but we mos definitely hear him as he passes various CONVENTION GOERS
sense_profile: we mos definitely hear him as he passes various CONVENTION GOERS

text: Hey Taco Bill, am I gonna see you at Horizons tonight? I hear they got their all-you-care-to-eat pussy buffet going! A booming laugh follows as the feet continue down the hal

Tim admires Ronald's laptop. The screen saver is a photo billboard advertising Ronald Wilkes Insurance. A picture stoic-looking Ronald is the centerpiece of the billboard along with the slogan, Your Insurance Professional. 26. Cedar Rapids, 6-12-09
So far it's just the one billboard north of St. Cloud. Course the traffic load would get me more eyeballs in the Twin Cities corridor, but at the end of the day, it's N-T- S. Not Too Shabby.

Ha. N-T-S. That's hilarious. I'd love to own my own agency... The door bursts open. We boom up from the scuffed wing-ti to reveal DEAN ZIEGLER, 45, whose massive personality jus barely hides an undercurrent of sadness and insecurity.
Baroo-baroo, let's get this party started you mother-rubbers! Ronald deflates upon seeing Dean. He clearly knows him.
Ronald Wilkes! No fucking way! The Ronimal! Gimme some love-uh, my soul broth-uh! Dean gives Ronald a bear hug, lifts him off the ground.
Turn down the volume, Ziegler. You just got here, for Pete's sake. Tim looks like someone deciding which direction to run fr an oncoming tornado. Dean notices Tim's look.

What's the matter, friend, never seen a chocolate-vanilla love sandwich?! Wait until later when we get to the buttfucking! Nah, I'm having fun. Dean Ziegler. Stevens Point, Wisconsin. Tim discreetly looks at the checklist Krogstad gave him. Under AVOID, it says DEAN ZIEGLER.
Don't worry, I won't bite. I'm medicated. Not really. But I should be. Right Ronimal? So what's your handle pal? 27. Cedar Rapids, 6-12-09

PayPal. That's where. What has ASMI ever given Orin Helgesson? Huh? Not dime one. Sure as shoot not an opportunity to serve on the National Board. Have I not been a good President? Do I not deserve a little something?

There aren't printing costs anymore, see? The ASMI-teer's digital. E- Commerce! Don't you get it, Tim? All that money-- almost 39-hundred dollars a year-- that goes into a PayPal account now. My PayPal account. But I've got no idea how to use it. 87. Cedar Rapids, 6-12-09
Do you literally mean you just need help, like, getting on-line, or...?

Pontoon boats don't pay for themselves, Tim. Roger Lemke came to the prom. He showed me a little teat. I rewarded him with the Two Diamonds three years running. I'm prepared to do the same for you. What do you say? You take home those those Two Diamonds, Northlands' value skyrockets, Bill Krogstad retires to his time share. Everybody wins... We push in on Tim-- at the crossroads of all crossroads. Outside, a clap of thunder booms ominously.
I'd be doing it for Northlands-- to keep it in Brown Valley and help my co-workers. To help Bill... Tim looks away, avoiding eye contact. Then:
What would you need me to do exactly...? Orin claps once, smiles like a proud grandparent.
OK, marvelous!
Dean has dozens of Hello My Name Is stickers with "Deanzi For President!" written on them. He forces one on a WOMAN 88. Cedar Rapids, 6-12-09
Vote for Deanzie. Vote for change.

Um. I... I don't know about that.

I'm sorry about... Ronald. Just... about everything... Tim abruptly walks away. Dean and Ronald look at each oth perplexed, as Tim exits the hotel into the pouring rain.
A cold, hard rain falls as Tim walks from the Holidome to an Applebee's across the busy street. 89. Cedar Rapids, 6-12-09
Tim enters and walks to the bar. He's soaking wet and loo despondent. A cheery female bartender, KAY, 40, greets hi

A large cream sherry, please. As she pours a healthy glass of sherry:
Looks like you could use some cheering up. What do you call it when it rains chickens and ducks?
Fowl weather.
That's pretty hilarious. Tim slams the sherry in one gulp-- to Kay's dismay.
Another please. I have to use the little boy's room. Kay watches as Tim heads for the bathroom. He leaves his phone on the bar.
Tim pees at the urinal. He zips up, goes to wash his hand In the mirror, he's shocked to see: A squinty, drugged ou MAN, 25, exit the stall, followed by... Bree. A moment of recognition.

Bree? (off her confused look) It's Tim Lippe. From the ASMI convention. We met out in front of the Holidome across the street? Bree coughs a hacking, phlegmy cough. She's very out of i 90. Cedar Rapids, 6-12-09

Ooh, that's really awesome of you to ask. But I have a super important presentation in the morning unfortunately, so... The squinty-eyed man, GARY, who has been drinking out of sink, looks up at Tim.
I gotta work in the morning, too. Can't be productive or whatever without occasionally taking a little ride on the good times express. It's like, fuck that shit, yo.

Seriously. We're going to this thing at my Uncle Ken's later-- after his shift's done. Bree examines Tim, standing stiffly, hands in his pockets
You look like you're in serious need of some relaxation, dude. Bree nonchalantly pinches his nose. Tim looks oddly touch

Mike Pyle, in a bold chartreuse sweater vest, quietly con with Orin outside a conference room.
My advice, Mike? Pull the trigger. I've pretty well convinced him that his company's in the crapper. 85- thousand is as low as I could possibly get him.

WEDDING GUESTS do the chicken dance. Krogstad strains to heard over the music.
Y'know what Orin, it's only a seven hour drive to Cedar Rapids. If I leave right now, I can be there first thing in the A-M and we can lock this sonofagun down.

And so you're not really like, living your own life fully? But dude, let me tell you this: the only real insurance in this life-- is love. That did it. Now Tim is weeping. Bree notices.

The Ronimal! The minivan speeds through the dark, rainy night.

Sleep good, little friend. Dean and Ronald head for the bedroom. Tim looks at Joan.
I didn't make love to Bree, Joan.
It doesn't matter. Here, lie down, Lippe. Tim rests his head on Joan's lap. His eyes are still on f

Orin stirs in his king-size bed. The knocking is at his d He gets out of bed, puts on a robe and goes to the door. peeks through the eyehole.

Oh shit...

Sweet love showin' us a heavenly light. I never seen such a beautiful sight! See love glowin' on us every night, I know forever we'll be doin' it right! Tim drives past a farm and sees dozens of hogs foraging around in a sloppy pen. He stomps the brakes, sliding dangerously onto the muddy shoulder.
Tim gets out of the car. The peppy song is still playing. sings along as he dances to the back of the car.

I always wanna call you "friend!" Sweet love showin' us a heavenly... Tim opens up the trunk. That's when we see: INSIDE THE TRUNK: Orin, in his pajamas, bound and gagged Holiday Inn bedsheets. His shouts are muffled by the gag. Tim pulls Orin from the trunk. Orin's feet are tied toget so he has to hop as Tim leads him toward the hog farm.
Careful. It's super slippery. Orin falls face first into the muddy ditch.
Whoop. Careful now. 105. Cedar Rapids, 6-12-09 Tim helps Orin to his feet. Several enormous HOGS rush to them on the other side of a barbed wire fence.
(terrified, through gag) Nmmmmmmmmm!

I did a ton of research on hog farm risk mitigation. Don't worry-- they might bite you a little if they think you're a food source. But there's never been a recorded hog- bite death. So... With great difficulty, Tim picks up Orin. Then, he awkwar hurls him over the barbed wire fence. Orin lands on his b in a deep pile of mud and hog shit. The hogs descend.

The Two Diamonds may be meaningless to you and Bill. But there are people who care about this stuff. Ronald Wilkes. Even Dean. Honest, good people. I'll come back for you after the Two Diamonds have been handed out to a legitimate winner. I'm really sorry about this, Orin, but the insurance industry deserves better than you. Tim goes to his car, leaving Orin wriggling with the hogs
A HUSBAND and WIFE sleep. Their phone rings. They stir. T clock says 6:45 AM. The woman rolls over.
Who the heck's calling at this hour on a Sunday morning? The man answers the phone. (NOTE: We should now recognize couple as the clients Tim dealt with in the Northlands conference room.)
Hello.
Kurt Gambsky, Tim Lippe-- your insurance agent. How's Pam and the girls? 106. Cedar Rapids, 6-12-09
(whispers to wife) Tim Lippe.
Um, fine, Tim. We're fine. Everything OK by you?
Tim talks on his cell as he drives.
Well, I think everything's OK. Hope it is anyway. Listen Kurt, here's why I'm calling...
An eagle soars on a large video screen. A patriotic anthe plays. We boom down from the screen to find Ronald. He's stage finishing up his Two Diamond presentation.

People sometimes say that promises are cheap. You know what Ronald Wilkes says to that? N-S-F. Not so fast. At the end of the day, a man's word is a sacred creed. And the word I give you at Ronald Wilkes Insurance is-- I will work for you. Thank you. The words, "Ronald Wilkes Insurance: Working For You" app on screen. Ronald's face dissolves over the eagle. The CROWD goes nuts, applauding wildly. Dean and Joan sta standing ovation. Ronald, though exhausted, beams on stag Tim is nowhere to be found. An EXECUTIVE COUNCIL MEMBER addresses the crowd.

Once again folks, President Helgesson left a note under my door this morning saying he had to leave ASMI early due to a family emergency. I haven't been able to reach him on his mobile, but obviously our thoughts and prayers go out to Orin and his family.
Cedar Rapids, 6-12-09
(a moment of silence) Now... we're set to hear our final Two Diamond presenter. Tim Lip from Northlands Insurance. Tim? Joan, Dean and Ronald exchange worried looks. Dean stands
sense_profile: to hear our final Two Diamond presenter

text: Hey Travis, I don't think Tim... Just then, Tim appears. He is filthy-- covered in mud, sw hog shit and tears. He futilely smooths his hair and trie tuck in his shirt as he takes the stage to sparse applaus Tim goes to the computer set up on stage for Power Point. puts in his disc. His presentation appears on the screen.
Thank you. I'm Tim Lippe. Hog farm risk mitigation... What is...? Tim knocks a folder off the podium. Papers fly everywhere

Smooth move, Ex-Lax. (a few chuckles) So, Hog... No. I, ah... this girl I met, sorry woman, I guess. She's 23. She takes drugs, and I think might be some kind of prostitute. (a collective gasp) But she's super insightful. Y'know what she said to me last night? Said the only real insurance is love. That's fricking INTENSE, isn't it...? Awkward murmurs. At this moment, a very pleased Bill Krog walks in with Mike Pyle. Krogstad tenses, however, when h sees Tim's state.
I'm... ah... Our only true safety net. Love. Crazy. I believe in insurance. I believe in love... Tim laughs. He looks up and sees Bill.
Bill! Bill Krogstad. My former boss, everybody. 108. Cedar Rapids, 6-12-09
What're you doing, Lippe?
Why'd you do this, Bill? I don't understand. Krogstad chuckles, preferring to avoid any public drama.
Why'd you do it, Bill? Why'd you do it? Why'd you lie, Bill?
(to the audience) Sorry, folks. Guess it's against the law now for a business owner to sell his own business. Must've missed that constitutional amendment. This draws chuckles from the crowd.
Insurance isn't just a business, Bill. Insurance is personal. I've got some savings. I could've gotten a loan. We could've worked something out.
(still playing to the crowd) Yeah, there's a guy you want running an agency, isn't it?
Come on, Tim, you're tired. You're looking foolish here. You couldn't run an agency if your life depended on it. Tim's lip starts to quiver, and with great effort:
Screw you, Bill. Screw you... hard.

That's a bunch of dog crap. You and Lemke, that... fucking pervert... you stole my ideas and called them your own for years. And I didn't say squat-- because I figured we were like a family. I may not have quite as many clients as Roger had. But my people are loyal, Bill.
Cedar Rapids, 6-12-09
I care about them. And guess what, they care about me. Fact, I've called more than half of them already this morning...
Watch yourself, Lippe...

I knew which ones would be on their way to church, which ones I'd be waking up, which ones probably got a little blotto last night and might be hung over... And every single person I talked to-- every one-- is staying with me.
You don't know what you're doing.

I do actually. I do know, Bill. And before the day is out, I'll have called all my clients. All of them. (to Mike Pyle) So hey, congratulations Pyle of Shit-- you just bought a company that's losing half its business.
Fuck yeah Timbo! Mike Pyle blinks several times. Krogstad seethes. Before can fully bask in the glow of his triumph:
Right there, officer. That's him. Orin, still in his pajamas and caked in hog shit, points CEDAR RAPIDS COPS in Tim's direction. Tactful pandemonium ensues. Dean, Ronald and Joan rush to Tim's side.
Jesus Lippe, what did you do? Aw jeez. This is no good.
What's the fucking charge?
Here. Before the cops get to him, Tim hands Dean a crumpled pie of paper. 110. Cedar Rapids, 6-12-09
What's this?
You'll figure it out. A cop cuffs Tim and leads him out of the ballroom.
Tim sits on a metal bench in a dank holding cell.
I know what you're thinking-- thinking "this wiseacre's full of baloney." Am I right? Reveal: He's chatting with a massive black man, REGINALD,
But I'm telling you Reginald, you're actually a perfect candidate for term life... A GUARD opens the cell door.
Tim Lip?
He pronounce it like Lippy.
Well, you're outta here, Lippe. Tim hands Reginald a business card.
I'm serious. Call any time-- on the mobile or home phone, though. The office number's no good anymore. Reginald gives Tim a warm hug.
Thanks Tim. You're all right. 111. Cedar Rapids, 6-12-09
Tim walks out of the jail into the bright sunlight. Dean there waiting for him. They walk toward Dean's minivan.
Don't even say it, Deanzie-- no one butt rammed me or whatever in there.
"Butt ram!" I love it! Dean gives Tim a hug. He then pulls a crumpled piece of p from his pocket-- it's the sheet Tim gave him earlier.
Want your get out of jail free card back?
Not particularly.
When I saw it, at first I was like, shit am I supposed to take money out of the account, or what?
Did you?
Nah, it was more fun watching the smug fuck sweat. I told him I'd rat his pathetic ass out if he didn't drop the charges against you.
(a genuine smile) Sweet. Dean tosses the paper into the trash. We now see what it On Holiday Inn stationary, in Tim's scrawl: www.paypal.co Username: OrinHelgesson. Password: PontoonMan123.

Dean drives. Ronald rides shotgun. Tim and Joan are in ba The minivan cruises past downtown Cedar Rapids. Tim looks at the buildings. So tall. Ronald considers his Two Diamond plaque. 112. Cedar Rapids, 6-12-09
It's not as cool as I thought it'd be. I don't think this is even real wood.

(lacking his usual energy) I'll show you some real wood. Ronald starts giggling. It turns into a laugh. The laugh becomes infectious. Before long, Tim, Joan, Ronald and De are all laughing their asses off.
Dean, Ronald and Joan accompany Tim, now cleaned up, to t airport. Tim sets down his old American Tourister.
Well.
Deep subject. D'aar. Get it? (punches his arm) I told you you were a hero, Lippe. Insurance Man saves the day!
Tss. Ruined it more like.
True sign of a good day.
Well, pal, it's been real.
I'm gonna miss you guys.
Yeah. You bet.

Listen, my cousin Bob-- guy made a truckload selling these little scented pine trees all the ragheads hang in their cabs? Fuckin' believe that? Anyhow, he's got a sweet cottage up on Lake of the Woods. Canada? I can use it whenever I want.
Cedar Rapids, 6-12-09
I say we book it for June, before the mosquitoes go apeshit up there.
More time in a tightly enclosed space with Ziegler. Gee, sign me up.
I think it sounds awesome.
Actually, me too. The Ronimal could use a vacation.
Done. Dean picks Tim up in a bear hug, spins him around. Ronald gives Tim a more subdued hug. Then there's Joan.
So. Keep in touch. E-mail, all that good stuff.
You bet. You bet. You too.
If you're ever-- not that you would be-- ever in Oh-my-God, Nebraska...
Yeah. Mutual of Omaha's Wild Kingdom. I used to watch that. Would be cool some day to see.
Yeah. Look me up.

So. He puts out his hand. She laughs and hugs him instead. Ti closes his eyes. She feels so good. Smells so good. Joan's eyes are wide open. She swallows hard. She will no cry. It's OK. Keep telling yourself everything will be OK
Cedar Rapids, 6-12-09

Tim looks out the window, watching the city lights of Ced Rapids fade away. He catches his reflection in the window exhales. He smiles a little. Tim relaxes in his seat. He looks at his seat mate, a pleasant-looking WOMAN in her mid-30s.
sense_profile: the city lights of Ced Rapids

text: So, did you do anything fun in Cedar Rapids...?
SUPERSCRIPT: One Day Later

Tim loads a plate with macaroni, meatloaf, peas and mashe potatoes. Millie selects fish, potatoes, rice and corn. They wordlessly walk from the buffet to a booth. They sit start eating in silence. After a bit:
sense_profile: with macaroni , meatloaf , peas and mashe potatoes

text: How's the walleye?
Decent. Not bad.
Meatloaf's on the dry side.
Mm. Tim tries to smile at Millie. He is surprised to see that eyes are filling with tears.

What's...? Without saying a word, Millie struggles to pry the small diamond engagement ring from her sausage-like finger. Finally, she gets it off and hands it to Tim. He thinks of protesting. Instead, he takes the ring and p it in his pocket. Millie sniffles a bit, composes herself Tim opens his mouth to say something. Before he can think anything to say: 115. Cedar Rapids, 6-12-09 Wade sits down with a ridiculously full plate of food.
Shit, where were they hidin' the meatloaf...?
Tim dumps birdseed in the feeder. Sunlight filters throug the tree branches. The snow is starting to melt.
You're just gonna attract red squirrels with that junk, Tim. Tim smiles at his old, gnarled neighbor, LESLIE, 80.
How ya doin' there, Leslie?
Ach, I'm too old to give a shit. They take off their gloves to shake hands. Leslie won't l go of Tim's hand-- the way old men sometimes do.
Bill Krogstad told me he's switching our policy to some fella down in Milwaukee. Allstate. Says I won't notice a bit of difference in coverage or nothin'.
No, you probably won't.
Mm. Anyhow, I told the cocksucker to go fuck himself. Says I'm going with Tim Lippe. A man I can trust.
It's a good thing you're doin'-- keepin' work in Brown Valley.
I'm trying... Leslie pats Tim on the shoulder. As he heads back inside: 116. Cedar Rapids, 6-12-09

Let me know when them red squirrels show up at your feeder. I'll borrow you my 22. Tim chuckles. He goes back to his yard. He pauses. At his feeder: A robin. A sure sign of spring. An uplifting song fades in, along with:
The chances we take in life are called risks.
- ON A LAKE: Tim is pulled behind a boat on waterskis. He falls face first, skipping across the lake.

We pay insurance companies premiums as a way of hedging our bets, in case those risks we take cause us or our property harm. - AT A BALL DIAMOND: Tim, playing in a summer softball league, slides headfirst into third base.

That's the point of insurance-- so we can live and love life to the fullest. - AT A STRIP MALL: A COUPLE walks past a discount shoe st and into TIM LIPPE INSURANCE. The camera follows them int the cramped, decidedly unimpressive office. Tim, seated a desk, looks directly at the camera and stiffly addresses
sense_profile: past a discount shoe st and into TIM LIPPE INSURANCE.

text: At Tim Lippe Insurance, we can't guarantee that you'll live your life without devastating losses. But we can give you peace of mind-- knowing that if something awful or unfortunate does happen-- we'll have you covered. Tim Lippe Insurance. Insuring your Home and your Hopes. 117. Cedar Rapids, 6-12-09 A fanciful unicorn prances across the screen, and we:
REVEAL: Tim, Dean and Ronald have been watching Tim's ad TV at a lakeside cabin. Tim looks proudly at his friends.
Can I be honest here, Tim?
You bet.
What was with the fuckin' unicorn?
What? It represented hope...
All's I'm saying is you might've wanted to hire an actor with some professional training...
Jesus-- a retarded kid just sitting there yelling would've been better than you.
Aw, you're both a couple of a- holes... Tim whips an empty beer can at Dean. The three friends la living life in the moment. As it should be.
